title: Friday, 23rd June, 2017

PM11:05am

here's a taste of his Evidence Lab thing on the banks and housebuilders

PM11:05am

A focus on the UK consumer as the UK begins Brexit negotiationsA good proportion of current UK client meetings are devoted to discussing the outlook for the consumer. As the economy slows – we forecast a halving in GDP growth YoY in 2018 – and government negotiates terms of the EU exit, we intend to publish regular research under the 'Brexit Brief' banner covering sector level developments which affect household finances. This work will include input from strategy, macro-economics and bottom-up analysts. This piece includes UBS Evidence Lab insights into current mortgage and savings rates as well as selling conditions in the housing market.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

A debt- and housing-driven economy: View from the banks...This Brexit Brief examines the outlook for UK credit growth as a driver of GDP. Residential mortgages, at 88% of household debt, matter most. Despite expecting a GDP slowdown, rising unemployment and modestly lower house prices, we forecast 2-4% p.a. growth in mortgages outstanding over the next five years. This is driven by the upside from leveraging the 50% of UK homes which are mortgage-free and applying more leverage to the currently-indebted. Our analysis shows it is logical for banks to expand this business, which already makes up 86% of retail lending profit.

PM11:06am

We are at close to peak stimulus – Will we ever return to normal?

PM11:06am

The economic stimulus from cheap central bank liquidity and Government support of new house buyers through Help to Buy (HTB) is likely close to its peak, in our view. So unless the BoE funding schemes – currently funding 1-28% of bank loans – are extended we may see debt costs rise in 2018. Possible regulatory intervention in unsecured lending might impact credit and consumer spend. The fate of the new build market will also likely be influenced by what happens to HTB following its 2021 expiry

11:07 am
PM11:07am

There's a price for everything: Buy Barclays, LBG, housebuilders Despite the cautious backdrop we see selective opportunities within the UK banks with the prices of Barclays and LBG discount too much risk and too little execution in our view. UBS Evidence Lab data shows LBG taking a more aggressive pricing stance in mortgages increasing our confidence in their lending targets. In the housebuilders we have become more selective but with the sector trading on 8x CY18E P/E and yielding 6%, we see value. Our top picks are Bellway, Berkeleyand Redrow

PM11:07am

There's 30 pages which I will try and usual place later

PM11:08am

PM11:08am

11:08 am
BE11:08am

I still get Nomura stuff as a legacy of when they used to be a broker.

BE11:09am

It has been a rollercoaster of a week when it comes to central bank commentary, with
Governor Carney’s Mansion House address justifying no change in interest rates but
Chief Economist Haldane highlighting the need for a possible imminent reversal of last
year’s loosening. On balance, we have decided to change our view and now expect the
MPC to raise interest rates by 25bp on 3 August. With the Bank growing increasingly
intolerant of above-target inflation, it has begun to feel that weaker data would now be
needed to prove the case for keeping policy on hold, rather than stronger data being
required to justify higher rates.
Should the Bank opt to raise rates in August we could not say that we had not been
warned given recent commentary in the MPC’s minutes and speeches. A decision to
hike would need to be based in part on expectations that above-target inflation will
eventually lead to second-round effects (wages and inflation expectations). After all, the
Bank has shown its willingness to change policy on expectations in the past in last
August’s post-referendum loosening. We think the Bank will deliver a “dovish hike” on 3
August by virtue of any associated commentary highlighting a) the move being a reversal
of last year’s cut, b) that policy is still highly accommodative, and c) that future moves will
be “gradual and limited”. Indeed, we would not expect a move in August to be followed
by another hike sooner than the February 2018 meeting.

BE11:09am

So, a “dovish hike” at its 3 August meeting

11:09 am
BE11:09am

There are two
ways this could be achieved:
 To explain in its commentary that it would be merely a reversal of the rate cut
part of last August’s easing package, and that with the new level of rates at just
0.50% and the stock of QE intended to remain in place for some time (at least
until Bank Rate reaches “a level from which it can be cut materially” – Carney,
November 2015), policy remains exceptionally accommodative.
 To emphasise what the MPC said in its June meeting, that “any [future]
increases in Bank Rate would be expected to be at a gradual pace and to a
limited extent”.
We believe that a combination of both statements would be appropriate, from an
expectations management point of view, in the event that the Bank does raise rates in
August.

BE11:10am

Sorry about the lumpy formatting.

BE11:10am

From a top-down approach, it looks to us that stronger economic data are pushing on an
open door: there seems to be a sense of increased willingness among the MPC to take
back some of the easing that was put in place in response to the Brexit vote a year ago.
However, from a bottom-up approach we must remember that in forecasting BoE policy
in any given month we are essentially making a judgment on how the above individual
members of the Committee will vote.
Our new view is that – should the data remain on its current trajectory over the coming
six weeks – there is nothing to prevent the MPC from deciding to take back 25bp of
monetary policy accommodation at its next meeting on 3 August. Even if every piece of
economic news is not pointing in the right direction (average weekly earnings growth
remains weak, for example) there is a growing sense that current “emergency” monetary
policy settings are no longer appropriate, providing the wrong incentives and signals to
households and firms almost a decade on from the credit crisis. A clear window of
opportunity currently exists for the MPC to raise interest rates – we now expect that the
Committee will embrace this at its next meeting on 3 August and vote to raise interest
rates by 25bp.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Which isn't currently the consensus, nor what's priced in, but I'd be unsurprised to see a drift that direction in the coming weeks.

PM11:20am

I see Merrill Lynch are already on my summer drift theme

11:20 am
PM11:21am

Summer drift – positioning for mid-cycle

PM11:21am

As a heatwave engulfs Europe, equities may suffer from sticky conditions near term. Bullish sentiment, slowing cyclical momentum, weak oil and policy uncertainty (fiscal, monetary, China) could cause a wobble. At least upside will be capped without clarity. We stay positive on 6-month view. Our base case is for a mid / late cycle environment in which equities historically tended to perform well. Other positive factors include politics (BTP-bund spread lower), M&A, dividend yield above credit, upside to flows.

PM11:21am

What to watch - growth, wages, policy and credit

11:21 am
PM11:21am

The jury is still out on the US economy given mediocre hard data. Surveys are upbeat and mean reversion will help - the pace of downside surprises in the US is near trough levels. Inflation is subdued but any sign of life - notably wage growth - would be pivotal for rates and reflation trades. Ditto any confirmation of a relatively soft landing in China. Central bank watchers will have to wait till September. The same is probably true for US fiscal policy - even if expectations are low. Importantly credit markets remain sanguine.

PM11:21am

Cyclical momentum slowing - benign outside recessions…

PM11:21am

We think it is premature to call for an end to the cycle, but leading indicators (PMIs, OECD) point to a slowing in cyclical momentum globally. Peaks in cyclical indicators are actually quite benign for equity indices outside recessions. Equities average 19% returns after 12 months in mid-cycle episodes. The current combination of positive EPS revisions and PMIs above 55 typically lasts for longer and false peaks are common.

11:22 am
PM11:22am

…but argues for more balanced sector allocation

PM11:22am

Peaks in cyclical indicators argue for a balance between cyclical and defensive sectors. Returns are markedly more defensive in recessionary periods but that is much less definitive in mid-cycle periods. We assume no recession but do reduce our cyclical bets today. We moved the sector allocation in a more overtly reflationary direction in late April. That hasn't worked and the decline in oil prices has been particularly costly. We revert to the more balanced approach we ran from late 2016 given our concerns that catalysts for reflation type trades may be lacking over the summer.

PM11:23am

Trouble with trying to call the cycle is QE

We revise our estimates for Inmarsat with our (previously) above-consensus
forecast EBITDA (ex Ligado) falling 3-4% over 2017-19E as we lower margins at
Enterprise and Maritime, partly offset by better performance in the Government
segment. We revise our D&A estimates, which increase 9% in 2018E and 13% in
2019E. We also raise our interest cost forecasts as we'd allowed our rate
assumption to go too low. Consequently, our EPS estimate declines 11% in 2017E
and 21% in 2018E. Our capex estimate increases by 11 -12% in 2018-19. We retain
our Neutral rating and price target of £7.70.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

For a number of years, Domino’s delivered very strong revenue growth in the UK, before momentum slowed at the start of 2017. While we initially thought this would bounce back quickly, we increasingly believe that some issues could create continued pressure on near-term performance. Some of these have the potential to become longer-term problems but we still feel that, as long as they are dealt with, Domino’s could successfully build a larger business in the UK over time. However, given the near-term challenges, we downgrade to Hold and reduce our price target to GBp325.

BE11:31am

PM11:01am

Welcome to ML

11:32 am
PM11:32am

What's the GPS tracking angle?

BE11:33am

Know where your pizza is.

BE11:33am

So you can intercept it and mug the delivery man.

11:33 am
PM11:33am

The idea of the Domino's GPS Driver Tracker was born out the thinking – “How do we make our driver fleet safer?”
Our drivers are the heart of our organisation and with new technology we now have the ability to keep them and the driver environment much safer. With GPS Driver Tracker Domino’s has been able to make sure our drivers are always driving within the speed limit and we can also measure the harshness of driving. As a result of the invention of the Domino’s GPS Driver Tracker, we’ve been able to reduce our incidents by 50%.
Domino’s GPS Driver Tracker links the online ordering experience with the store delivery driver so customers know exactly when their pizza order is leaving the store and how long it will take to get to their house. In fact, it provides the customer access to watch the route the driver takes to get to their place in real-time.
With the technology active, Domino’s stores can now record and measure a lot of data they never before had transparency over. This includes the exact time it took to do the delivery, even down to the second. They can see the route the driver took to get to the destination and compare that with the optimum way to go, which is worked out by distance, time and traffic.

BE11:34am

Yep, I'm not going to be reading that.

PM11:34am

11:34 am

BE11:35am

Anyway, going to point out again that Domino's should have opened its app up to non-competing sector peers five or so years ago. And I'm going to mention that they've missed the window, which wouldn't have happened if they'd gone for the idea when I first suggested it.

BE11:35am

Back to Berenberg.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Market uncertainty: One of the reasons given for the low lfl growth at the start of 2017 was a weak consumer environment. At the time, we noted the lack of evidence for this. However, since then a host of consumer facing companies have highlighted the uncertain market conditions and spending data has softened. Given the potential internal issues and the possibility of a more subdued external environment, we reduce our 2017E UK lfl growth forecast to 1.5%.

BE11:36am

Valuation: Domino’s trades on 19.4x 2017E P/E for 9% 2017-19E EPS CAGR

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Well, the argument is that ITV's in a structurally declining bit of the ad market in an economy that's going off a cliff.

BE11:41am

But it's in the price already.

BE11:41am

Everything appears bad: (i) Advertising is weak at ITV with NAR down c5% in H2
2016 and -8/9% in H1 2017. (ii) The market is cautious on stocks exposed to a
potentially weakening UK economy. (iii) ITV could have a third successive
advertising down year in 2018. (iv) There is a gradual structural shift to digital in
the ad mix. (v) ITV’s CEO of the last seven years is leaving. (vi) Studios did -7%
organic revenue growth in 2016. (vii) Eps revisions have been consistently
negative in the last 18 months. (viii) ITV’s H1 2017 will be weak due to timing
effects. (ix) The chairman of Liberty Global, which owns 9.9% of ITV, recently said
that he thinks ITV ‘trades at a pretty full valuation today’.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Another eps downgrade: Since the start of 2016 our 2017-18 eps forecasts have
dropped by 21%-27%. The share price is down 36% in the same period. We now
conservatively take our advertising forecasts to the low end/below what media
buyers are predicting. We are at -6.5% in 2017 and -1% in 2018. Our eps forecasts
fall by 3% in 2017 and 4-5% in 2018-20.

BE11:42am

Valuation is very attractive: At 177p ITV’s 2017 p/e of 11.5x makes it the most
lowly rated share in all of European Media. It trades on a healthy FCF yield of 7%
(7.4% excluding one off HQ capex), an ordinary yield of 4.3% and, assuming
another 5p special dividend, a potential total dividend yield of 7.1% - the highest
in Media. The business is in good shape. We think ITV was early into the
advertising downturn and that its impact is largely discounted in the shares.

BE11:42am

News flow about to improve: Timing is always tricky but typically the right
moment to buy TV stocks is when advertising starts to improve, even if this is just
on a second derivative basis (i.e. it starts to become less bad). June 2017 should
mark the low point for ITV advertising. We forecast the Q1-Q4 quarterly
progression at ITV in 2017 to be -9%, -8.4%, -5.3% -3.3%. With a weak comp and
boosted by Easter, Q1 18 could be flat. With the World Cup, ad growth could be
+5% to +8% in Q2 18. We think our forecasts are appropriately low with the risk
on the upside. ITV may start to enjoy retransmission revenues (c£30m pa, not in
forecasts or price target) from the start of 2018. Studios will revert to organic
growth in 2017, audiences are robust and VoD advertising strong. We think ITV
will appoint a continuity CEO supportive of the existing producer /broadcaster
strategy. The presence of a 9.9% shareholder who ‘would love’ to own ITV, albeit
not at the current price (John Malone – FT 11 May) provides constant interest.
ITV ( ITV.L, ITV LN )
Morgan Stanley does and seeks to do business with
companies covered in Morgan Stanley Research. As a
result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a
conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of
Morgan Stanley Research. Investors should consider
Morgan Stanley Research as only a single factor in making
their investment decision.
For analyst certification and other important disclosures,
refer to the Disclosure Section, located at the end of this
report.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

The UK general election is shaping to be a tipping point for UK supply
markets, with a weakened Tory government opting for further consultation on
energy market reform rather than pressing ahead with a market-wide price
cap. In doing so, the government has effectively taken off the table the ‘worst
case’ scenario we had feared. While investors should feel some relief at this
development, there is a caveat: the specter of price regulation still hangs over
the industry, with Ofgem to explore further options to help the energy market
‘work better for all consumers’. In addition to this, the competitive threat
continues to gather momentum, with new entrants Engie and Vattenfall
entering the market in recent months. With risks now more evenly balanced,
we are upgrading to Neutral, with revised Target Price of 205p (180p).

BE11:52am

Chance of worst case outcome receding – The weight of opinion has
clearly shifted from expectations of full price regulation in the UK supply
market via a cap on SVT customers. At the core of this shift is the phrase
from this week’s Queen’s Speech with the government proposing to "extend
the price protection currently in place for some vulnerable customers to
more customers on the poorest value tariffs". Our conclusion from this is
that the likelihood of a market-wide cap has fallen and with it the worst case
outcome for sector earnings.

BE11:52am

Forecast and valuation adjustments – The removal of our more bearish
UK retail margin assumptions, sale of loss-making gas-fired generation
assets (Langage and South Humber Bank) and incremental production from
Rough cushion gas reserves drive a material upgrade in our estimates of
c.14% on average over the 2017-19 forecast horizon. The resultant valuation
boost is equally material – we have increased our Price Target from 180p to
205p, largely due to the impact of our retail assumptions.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

CMD provides useful insight into growth aspirations - Aside from
providing an update on group strategy, the main objective of this week’s
Capital Markets Day was to demonstrate the capabilities of the new
technology platform and outline its embedded growth potential

PM12:01pm

BE12:01pm

Though if you want a deep analysis of market dynamics for optical transmitters, receivers, and modulators, it's there for you.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

As Ethernet ramps to faster transmission speeds to power massive
cloud data centers, optical networking provides the enabling transport technology. 100 gigabit
Ethernet, structured around four lanes of 25 gigabit Ethernet, is just now being deployed at
attractive price points. Beyond the data center growth in the US is a massive Service Provider
build-out underway in China that OCLR is well positioned to leverage. Longer term we believe
demand will continue to be robust as Ethernet continues to push the speed curve, moving to
200 and 400 gigabits per second.

BE12:02pm

That kind of thing.

BE12:02pm

We are initiating coverage of Oclaro with a BUY recommendation and 12-month price target of $14

BE11:32am

Danger of falling behind the technology curve: Over the past few years, Domino’s has taken advantage of the market shift to online ordering as its e-commerce offering has been better than those of its traditional competitors. However, new players are changing the game and Domino’s is currently proving slow to react. The most notable example is GPS tracking. Although this is being trialled at present, its rollout will not begin until the second half of the year and no time scale has been determined for it to be introduced across the whole estate. Once implemented, we think it should provide a boost to lfl growth but until then rivals may capture more sales.
